qas.question: There are two types of sleep called what?
What type of sleep involves dreaming?
The three types of brain activity that can be measured are what?

answers.text: REM, light NREM and deep NREM

qas.question: Slow wave sleep is also known as what?
During what stage of sleep do serotonin and norepinephrine levels drop?

context: Sleep involves great changes in brain activity. Until the 1950s it was generally believed that the brain essentially shuts off during sleep, but this is now known to be far from true; activity continues, but patterns become very different. There are two types of sleep: <a0_0><a1_0>REM sleep<a1_0/> (with dreaming) and NREM<a0_0/> (non-REM, usually without dreaming) sleep, which repeat in slightly varying patterns throughout a sleep episode. Three broad types of distinct brain activity patterns can be measured: <a2_0>REM, light NREM and deep NREM<a2_0/>. During <a3_0>deep NREM sleep<a3_0/>, also called slow wave sleep, activity in the cortex takes the form of large synchronized waves, whereas in the waking state it is noisy and desynchronized. Levels of the neurotransmitters norepinephrine and serotonin drop during <a4_0>slow wave sleep<a4_0/>, and fall almost to zero during REM sleep; levels of acetylcholine show the reverse pattern.
